utterances: Yeah, sure
I'm happy to do that, sure.
I think if someone asks you, is the milk back in the back of the store because it's easier or because it makes you walk through the store, a safe answer is just to say yes.
David Kestenbaum, NPR News.
We first met Monzer Omar in Turkey.
The 33-year-old teacher fled there from Syria.
NPR began tracking his journey in Izmir, Turkey, when he was trying to board a smuggler's boat to Greece.
We followed him as he made his way through the chaos in Hungary, attempting to reach Austria.
And now he's made it to his final destination.
NPR's Eleanor Beardsley caught up with him.
Hello.
Hello.
Very nice to meet you.
You also.
Nice to meet you too.
You are so tired, yeah?
No. I'm OK.
Even though he's been the one on the move, Monzer Omar politely asks me if I'm tired.
We meet in front of the residence where he and about a hundred other migrants from Syria are being housed in the Northern German town of Warendorf.
Omar offers to pull my small suitcase as we walk into town to get something to eat.
We make our way along a tree-lined pedestrian and bike path.
Omar's been in Germany a month already, but some things are still hard to get used to, like adults riding bicycles.
It sounds like open warfare on the high seas, you know, very much, again, something that is almost out of a book.
What kind of rules apply to a situation like this?
Is it kind of, you know, anything goes?
Well, Farai, this is the irony here.
It is almost as if the Bush administration has militarized.
Again, in a foreign policy that puts the military first, it's almost like every nail is a hammer.
So you have seen the steady militarization of this area with U.S.
Navy operations very active, really for the last two years now, throughout these waterways.
But it hasn't made a difference.
Again, you have to go to the root causes of the crisis.
The root cause is the lack of a government and the lack of a viable economy there in Somalia.

Once you're able to create a space where people can make a living, have a decent wage, be able to put food on the table for their children, there will be less of a tendency towards this type of illicit activities.
So instead of further escalating the crisis, we need to look at really addressing the root causes to be able to create a more livable and peaceful Somalia.
Now inland, Islamist insurgents have been taking over towns in Somalia.
They took over the key port city of Merka without firing a shot.
These Islamists control a large and expanding region of south-central Somalia.
They're imposing Sharia, or fundamentalist Islamic law.
We're going to talk more about the impact of that religious law in a few minutes, but could these rebels take over Mogadishu, the capital?
Well, we have had now over these last few months a steady movement further of what is, in the eyes of many Somalis, a much more legitimate governing force than the one that's currently in place.
Remember, it was December, 2006, when the U.S.
actually ousted the Union of Islamic Courts in Somalia.
The Union of Islamic Courts had brought for a six month period when they ruled the first ever period of peace since 1992 for Somalia.
So you had this six-month window where people could send their children to school, women could walk in the streets freely, and there was a sense that life could begin again.
Yet because they had Islamic in their name, the Bush Administration decided no, that was unacceptable, and went forward, and working with Ethiopian ground troops and U.S.
air strikes, and also U.S.
naval operations, actually ousted that government.

What you have had since is an incursion of these now insurgents that have been organizing, steadily organizing and gaining strength throughout the country, and they are now right at the doorstep of Mogadishu according to many reports.

So it is very likely that this clamoring for a sense of determining their own future will lead to a more outright victory there in Somalia, and that you will have this current government that's been sort of propped up by Ethiopia and the United States in short order losing its legitimacy.
All right.
We have a couple of more things to touch on, not a lot of time, but a horrible story.

Again in Somalia, a young rape victim, some people say as young as 13, some people say as old at 23, but certainly a young girl or woman was publicly stoned to death for adultery in a very brutal situation after she said that she was raped by three men.
Do you think that there is any will to try to stop incidents like this?
And that policy, though certainly not, I think, universal, was related to an interpretation of religious law.
Who's going to stop it?
Well I think we have to be clear.
There are women living under Muslim law that are - some are facing extraordinary challenges, and many others are, in spite of living under Muslim law, are taking leadership in a number of areas.

You see human rights defenders all the way from western Sahara to Somalia, where women peace activists in Somalia have been clamoring for peace and justice in the country, not just for women but for all Somalis.

So I think we - because, again, of the difficult situation - we have to remember that Somalia is 90 percent Muslim, not extremist Muslim, but 90 percent Muslim, and we have to understand that there has to be a space to not hear Islam and not hear Muslim and hear extremist.
OK.
So clearly there is a lot of opportunity to work with Somali women, who are taking forward advances in women's rights, advances in women's political processes, even as we speak, Farai.
Emira, we really have just, you know, a tiny bit of time.
What should we keep our eyes on in the Congo?
Micro, micro.
Well, we've got to keep our eyes on the resources, the flow of resources from the Congo, the coltan that creates our cell phones and our computers, that is the root of the fighting in the Congo.
And until we can have a Congo where the resources serve the interests of the people we will continue to have crises like we do today.
Emira, thank you.
Thank you.
Emira Woods is co-director of Foreign Policy in Focus at the Institute for Policy Studies.
She joined us from our headquarters in Washington, D.C.
You've heard this before - do what you love and you'll never work a day in your life.
Sounds simple, but fitting artistry into industry takes compromise.
As Frannie Kelley reports, a Minneapolis musician is resisting commercial pressure with the help of funding from the art world.
Will Johnson has seen some things.
I got approached by Silicon Valley dudes.
And they basically were like, yo, we have created a formula to make a for-sure No. 1 hit - literally.
(SOUNDBITE OF FLUME'S ""PIKA"")
Johnson, who releases music under the name WILLS, did not get involved with those Silicon Valley dudes.
They approached him because he was already a successful songwriter with a publishing deal that had him co-writing with Grammy-winning names.
When someone vapes, be it a Juul or another brand, there's no fire, ash or smoky odor.
Public health officials worry it could be an emerging disaster.
Twenty-one-year-old Julien Lavandier says, believe it.
It's a habit for me all the time.
When I set down my schoolwork to do homework, take a rip of the Juul - when I get in my car, take a rip of the Juul.
Lavandier, a college student at CSU, says he started vaping when he was 16, a sophomore in high school.
It was common to smoke an e-cigarette at parties.
When vaping, you inhale water vapor through a device, an e-cigarette or other battery-powered inhaler, that heats up and vaporizes a liquid or solid.
At first, it was a lot of chasing flavors or doing smoke tricks, and that was really what impressed me.
I thought, you know, this is cool.
This looks like something fun.
He says students at his high school smoked in class without teachers knowing.
Lavandier started vaping regularly and later began smoking traditional cigarettes.
When Juul arrived on the market, he took up that brand.
It's impossible to let go once you've started using it.
I'll tell you after even an hour and a half or two, I am chomping at the bit to find my Juul.
Stores aren't supposed to sell e-cigarettes to minors, but Lavandier has been buying them for years and never been carded, not once, he says.
Representatives from Juul Labs in a statement say its products offer a true alternative to adult smokers, not anyone else, not minors.
Other companies that make e-liquids also say their products are not for minors, but Juul and other brands offer flavors like cotton candy, caramel and cookies and milk.
If they taste good and a kid might get their hands on, that's not our goal.
That's Jameson Rodgers.
He's with California-based NEwhere Inc, a producer of e-cigarette and vaping products.
He says its products comply with federal law, and it's up to retailers and distributors to not sell to minors.
Some of the responsibility has to fall on the parents of any kid that's deciding to walk into an adult store whether, that's a liquor store, or tobacco store, or whatnot.
One of the benefits of e-cigarettes, according to the industry, is that they can help people quit traditional smoking.
Ray Story is CEO of the Tobacco Vapor Electronic Cigarette Association.
Don't start at all.
But if you are going to smoke or do e-cigarettes, then certainly take an e-cigarette because it's vastly less harmful than conventional tobacco.
This is a new way to get kids addicted to nicotine.
Deb Liptzin is a pediatric pulmonologist at Children's Hospital Colorado.
She says there's been scant e-cigarette research.
They specifically used nicotine salts.
We have no research that I could find on nicotine salts that are inhaled because it's so new.
Data in Colorado shows e-cigarettes are far more popular than traditional cigarettes with high schoolers.
Jen Bolcoa is a health educator with Jefferson County schools.
The Juul has definitely been a game changer.
